Tweet: Arjuna said: For the sake of those who wish to transcend this material world, please explain the process of self-realization.
The imperishable origin of all beings has also been fully explained by Me in detail. O lotus-eyed one, this knowledge is the most profound and imperishable.
Thus, as You are, O Supreme Lord, I desire to see You, the sovereign, supreme person.
O Lord, if You think it is possible for me to see it, then, O Lord of Yoga, please show me Your imperishable Self.
The Blessed Lord said: Behold, O Arjuna, My forms, by hundreds and thousands, various in kind, divine, of various colors and shapes.
Behold the Adityas, Vasus, Rudras, Ashvins, Maruts, and many wonders never seen before, O Bharata.
"Behold now, Arjuna, the entire universe, with its moving and non-moving beings, all situated in one place in your body. And whatever else you wish to see."
But you cannot see me with your own eyes; therefore I give you divine eyes to see my majestic power.
Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus, the great Lord of Yoga, Hari, then showed His supreme form to Arjuna.
Many-faced, many-eyed, possessing many wondrous sights; adorned with many divine ornaments, wielding many divine weapons.
Wearing divine garlands and clothes, anointed with divine fragrances, the infinite deity, with faces in all directions, full of wonders.
If a thousand suns were to rise in the sky simultaneously, the splendor of that light would be like the splendor of the Supreme Being.
Then Arjuna saw the entire universe divided in many ways in the body of the God of gods.
Filled with wonder and hair standing on end, Arjuna, with folded hands, bowed his head to the Lord and spoke.
Arjuna said: O Lord, I see all the gods and various living entities assembled in Your body, as well as Brahma, the Lord seated on the lotus flower, and all the sages and divine serpents.
I see you with many arms, stomachs, faces, and eyes, I see you everywhere as infinite in form. There is no end, no middle, and no beginning to you, O Lord of the Universe, O Universal Form.
I see you, who is difficult to behold, shining in all directions like a blazing fire, with the radiance of the sun and fire, wearing a crown, holding a mace and discus.
You are the imperishable, the ultimate to be known. You are the supreme foundation of this universe. You are the imperishable protector of eternal dharma. You are the eternal person in my opinion.
I see You with Your face glowing like a thousand suns and blazing fire coming out of Your eyes, scorcing this universe with Your radiance.
O great soul, all the directions are overwhelmed upon seeing this terrible and fierce form of yours in the universe, situated between heaven and earth.

The groups of gods enter you, some frightened, with palms joined in reverence. The assemblies of great sages and perfected beings praise you, saying "Well-being to you," extolling you with abundant praises.
Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, Ashvins, Maruts, Ushmapas, Gandharvas, Yakshas, Asuras, and Siddhas all gaze at you in amazement.
Seeing your great and terrible form with many faces and eyes, O mighty-armed one, with many arms, thighs, and feet, with many bellies, with fearful teeth, the worlds are trembling, and so am I.
I do not find peace in seeing you, Vishnu, with your blinding, fiery eyes and multiple arms.
Seeing your terrifying, fiery mouths, I do not know the directions nor do I find peace. O lord of gods, please be gracious.
All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with their allied kings, Bhisma, Drona, and Karna, and all our soldiers are also there.
Your teeth are fearful and dreadful, shining in your mouth like fragments of scattered diamonds.
Just as many streams of water flow towards the ocean, similarly, the brave warriors of the human world enter your blazing mouths.
Just as moths enter a blazing fire to their destruction, so the people also enter your mouths with great speed for their own destruction.
You lick the entire universe with your tongues, your powerful radiance fills the entire world with brightness, O Vishnu, the blazing rays emanating from your body scorch all the directions.
Tell me who you are, O gracious form! Salutations to you, O divine one. Please be gracious, O god among gods. I desire to know you, the primeval one, for I do not understand your actions.

The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: Time I am, the great destroyer of the worlds, and I have come here to destroy all people. With the exception of you [the Pandavas], all the soldiers here on both sides will be slain.
Therefore, stand up and attain glory. Conquer your enemies and enjoy a prosperous kingdom. By My arrangement, these warriors are already defeated. Just be an instrument, O Savyasachin.
Defeat Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other brave warriors. You have already killed them. Therefore, stand up and fight. You will conquer your enemies in battle.
Sanjaya said: Having heard these words of Kesava, with folded hands and trembling, Arjuna, overwhelmed with fear, bowed down again and again and, with faltering voice, bowed down to Krishna.
Arjuna said: O Hrishikesha, the world delights and rejoices in Your praise. The demons are frightened, and all the directions are fleeing in fear. All the hosts of Siddhas bow down to You.

Therefore, I do not bow down to you, the great one, the first creator of Brahma. You are the infinite, the lord of gods, the dwelling place of the universe, the imperishable, the supreme goal of both the existent and the non-existent.
You are the original God, the ancient person, the supreme abode of this universe. You are the knower, the object of knowledge, and the supreme abode. By You, this universe is pervaded.
Air, Yam, Fire, Varuna, Moon, Prajapati, You are the great-grandfather. Salutations to you a thousand times, again and again salutations to you.
Salutations to you from the front, from behind, from all sides; you who are of infinite power and valor, you pervade all and therefore you are everything.
Thinking of you as a friend, O Krishna, O Yadava, thinking of you as my friend, not knowing your greatness, out of carelessness or love.
When you are made fun of, ignored, or insulted, or when you are alone, or even when you are with others, I will always forgive you, for you are immeasurable.

You are the father of this world, moving and non-moving. You are worthy of worship and the greatest teacher. There is no one superior to you. How then could there be anyone else in the three worlds whose power could be compared to yours?

Therefore, bowing down and prostrating before You, I seek Your grace, O Lord, worthy of being worshipped. Like a father with his son, like a friend with his friend, like a lover with his beloved, O God, please be kind to me.
I am delighted by the unexpected sight, yet my mind is troubled by fear. O Lord, reveal your divine form to me, O God of gods, the abode of the universe.
I desire to see you in that form with crown, mace, and discus in hand, in the same four-armed form; O universal form, thousand-armed, please become visible.

The Supreme Lord said: O Arjuna, by My grace, I have shown you this supreme form through My yogic power. This form is radiant, universal, beyond the beginning; it has never been seen before by anyone other than you.
Not by sacrifices, nor by study, nor by charity, nor by rituals, nor by severe austerities can I be seen in this form in the world of men by anyone else than you, O mighty armed one.
Do not be distressed. Do not be bewildered by seeing this terrible form of mine. With a cheerful mind and without fear, behold again this very form of mine.
Sanjaya said: Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Lord Krishna displayed His own divine form again. The Great Soul, calming Arjuna once more, showed His gentle form.
Arjuna said: O Janardana, seeing this human form of Yours, so very beautiful, I am now composed in mind, and I am restored to my original nature.

The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: My dear Arjuna, this form of Mine you are now seeing is very difficult to behold. Even the demigods are ever seeking the opportunity to see this form, which is so dear.
"I am not to be known by the Vedas, nor by austerity, nor by charity; not even by rituals can I be seen as you have seen me." (Bhagavad Gita 11.53)
By devotion alone can I be known as I am, Arjuna, and seen in this form, and entered into, O Parantapa.
One who performs his duty without attachment, surrendering the results unto the Supreme Lord, is unaffected by sinful action, as the lotus leaf is untouched by water.
